title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the fuel source that made the largest contribution to total electricity generated in 2011 by the ten countries as fossil fuels.
The response identifies the fuel source that made the largest contribution to total electricity generated in 2011 by the ten countries as fossil fuels.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the country that produced the greatest percentage of its electricity in 2011 from nuclear power as France.
The response identifies the country that produced the greatest percentage of its electricity in 2011 from nuclear power as France.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem in Brazil that could result if total electricity generation was increased by 10 percent with its least-used fuel source, such any of the following:

· Thermal pollution caused by returning heated coolant water from nuclear power plants to the source can decrease dissolved oxygen/increase BOD MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeOqaiaab+eacaqGebaaaa@3852@ of water disrupting aquatic organisms.

· Accidental release of radioactive waste into the environment from storage of used nuclear fuel rods and/or large-scale radioactive emissions from nuclear power plant disasters/explosions.

· Deforestation/habitat destruction or disruption from the construction of additional nuclear power plant sites.

· Increased land degradation from increased uranium mining for nuclear energy generation/nuclear fuel rods.

· Thermal pollution caused by returning heated coolant water from nuclear power plants to the source can decrease dissolved oxygen/increase BOD MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeOqaiaab+eacaqGebaaaa@3852@ of water disrupting aquatic organisms.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a solution to reduce an environmental problem linked to the primary fuel source used to generate electricity in Germany, other than reduced used of the fuel source, such as any of the following:

· Install wet or dry scrubbers/electrostatic precipitators/air pollution control devices to remove particulates and other pollutants from power plant emissions.

· Use carbon capture technology to convert/compress carbon dioxide gas into liquid and either store it underground/inject into depleted fossil fuel deposits to reduce/eliminate CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@386D@ emissions.

· Planting trees to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

· Create cleaner burning coal by converting the coal into a synthesis gas (syngas), which reduces greenhouse gas/pollution emissions.

· Enact stricter regulations/maintenance checks on oil drilling/mining/transportation to reduce instances of oil leaks/accidents/explosions.

· Increase energy efficiency of appliances, light bulbs, etc. to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The response proposes a solution to reduce an environmental problem linked to the primary fuel source used to generate electricity in Germany, other than reduced used of the fuel source, such as one of the following:

· Install wet or dry scrubbers/electrostatic precipitators/air pollution control devices to remove particulates and other pollutants from power plant emissions.

· Use carbon capture technology to convert/compress carbon dioxide gas into liquid and either store it underground/inject into depleted fossil fuel deposits to reduce/eliminate CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@386D@ emissions.

· Planting trees to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

· Create cleaner burning coal by converting the coal into a synthesis gas (syngas), which reduces greenhouse gas/pollution emissions.

· Enact stricter regulations/maintenance checks on oil drilling/mining/transportation to reduce instances of oil leaks/accidents/explosions.

· Increase energy efficiency of appliances, light bulbs, etc. to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that supports or refutes the hypothesis that the total ecological footprint of Japan was larger than that of India, such as any of the following:

· This is supported. Japan has a much smaller population than India, but Japan has a larger ecological footprint because Japan generates more total energy than India.

· This is supported. Based on per capita energy use and population size, Japan generates more total electricity than India and thus has a larger ecological footprint.

The response makes a claim that supports or refutes the hypothesis that the total ecological footprint of Japan was larger than that of India, such as one of the following:

· This is supported. Japan has a much smaller population than India, but Japan has a larger ecological footprint because Japan generates moretotal energy thanIndia.

· This is supported. Based on per capita energy use and population size, Japan generates more total electricity than India and thus has a larger ecological footprint.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that supports or refutes the proposed countrywide recycling program with curbside pickup to recycle single-use plastics as a way to reduce the ecological footprint of the country more than switching to reusable items like water bottles or shopping bags, such as any of the following:

· The claim is refuted because the energy required for curbside pickup, transport, and recycling would exceed the energy required to wash and reuse items.

· The claim is refuted because recyclable single-use plastics can be contaminated by other plastic and non-plastic waste, so they are no longer able to be recycled.

· Recycling may lead to making lower quality items, which does not reduce the amount of plastics being produced.

The response makes a claim that supports or refutes the proposed countrywide recycling program with curbside pickup to recycle single-use plastics as a way to reduce the ecological footprint of the country more than switching to reusable items like water bottles or shopping bags, such as one of the following:

· The claim is refuted because the energy required for curbside pickup, transport, and recycling would exceed the energy required to wash and reuse items.

· The claim is refuted because recyclable single-use plastics can be contaminated by other plastic and non-plastic waste, so they are no longer able to be recycled.

· Recycling may lead to making lower quality items, which does not reduce the amount of plastics being produced.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one regulatory practice that could reduce the effect of passenger vehicles on nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere, such as any of the following:

· Implement legislation to improve fuel quality standards/increase fuel efficiency of vehicles.

· Support/implement stricter vehicle emissions standards; require more frequent vehicle inspections specifically on older model vehicles.

· Invest/support research/use of alternative fuels, such biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel.

· Invest/support research/use of non-food-crop biofuels, such as those made from algae and switchgrass rather than corn.

· Incentives to switch to driving electric cars to reduce vehicle emissions.

· Incentives to increase carpooling to reduce the number of passenger vehicles emitting nitrogen oxides.

· Increased funding for public transportation to reduce the number of passenger vehicles emitting nitrogen oxides.

The response describes one regulatory practice that could reduce the effect of passenger vehicles on nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere, such as one of the following:

· Implement legislation to improve fuel quality standards/increase fuel efficiency of vehicles.

· Support/implement stricter vehicle emissions standards; require more frequent vehicle inspections specifically on older model vehicles.

· Invest/support research/use of alternative fuels, such biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel.

· Invest/support research/use of non-food-crop biofuels, such as those made from algae and switchgrass rather than corn.

· Incentives to switch to driving electric cars to reduce vehicle emissions.

· Incentives to increase carpooling to reduce the number of passenger vehicles emitting nitrogen oxides.

· Increased funding for public transportation to reduce the number of passenger vehicles emitting nitrogen oxides.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an additional benefit, other than reducing the air pollutant mentioned, that could result from the regulatory practice identified in part (g), such as any of the following:

Implement legislation to improve fuel quality standards/increase fuel efficiency of vehicles(regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Decreased use/purchase of gasoline, which would decrease reliance on fossil fuels and greenhouse gas emissions

Support/implement stricter vehicle emissions standards; require more frequent vehicle inspections specifically on older model vehicles (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Decrease in vehicular accidents and subsequent injuries/deaths caused by faulty/old vehicle parts/engines

Invest/support research/use of alternative fuels, such biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

Invest/support research/use of non-food-crop biofuels, such as those made from algae and switchgrass rather than corn (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Algae can be grown in wastewater from sewage treatment plants, reducing eutrophication from excessive of nutrients

· Growing switchgrass in the United States can provide wildlife habitat since it is a native grass

· There is a decrease in soil erosion and less depletion of carbon in the soil by growing/harvesting switchgrass than food crops such as corn

Incentives to switch to driving electric cars to reduce vehicle emissions (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

Incentives to increase carpooling to reduce the number of passenger vehicles emitting nitrogen oxides or increased funding for public transportation to reduce the number of passenger vehicles emitting nitrogen oxides (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Reduced traffic congestion
